title: 105_hr729
content: The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 is cited as the short title. It includes amendments to Title 5 of the United States Code and addresses the Civil Service Retirement System. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 includes provisions related to the maximum annuity allowable and years of service as a Member of Congress. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 includes provisions for computing an annuity based on years of service as a Member of Congress and Congressional Employee. This includes military service and Congressional employee service performed before a specific date. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 amends sections related to computing annuities based on years of service for Members of Congress and Congressional employees. Contribution rates are adjusted, with deductions of 7% of basic pay for employees and Members, and 7.5% for law enforcement officers. Technical amendments are made to ensure accurate calculations. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 adjusts contribution rates for Members of Congress and employees, with deductions of 7% of basic pay for employees and Members, and 7.5% for law enforcement officers. Additionally, 8% of basic pay is deducted for certain judicial positions. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 adjusts contribution rates for Members of Congress and employees, with deductions of 7% of basic pay for employees and Members, and 7.5% for law enforcement officers. Additionally, 8% of basic pay is deducted for certain judicial positions. After December 31, 1969, new rates will be implemented. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 adjusts contribution rates for Members of Congress and employees, with deductions of 7% of basic pay for employees and Members, and 7.5% for law enforcement officers. Additionally, 8% of basic pay is deducted for certain judicial positions. Effective January 1, 1970, new rates will be implemented. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 adjusts contribution rates for Members of Congress and employees, with deductions of 7% of basic pay for employees and Members, and 7.5% for law enforcement officers. Effective January 1, 1970, new rates will be implemented for congressional employee service. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 adjusts contribution rates for Members of Congress and employees, with deductions of 7% of basic pay for employees and Members, and 7.5% for law enforcement officers. New rates will be implemented for congressional employee service from January 1, 1970, onwards. SEC. 4. FEDERAL EMPLOYEES' RETIREMENT SYSTEM. Provisions related to years of service as a Member of Congress and Congressional Employee for computing an annuity are amended to reflect service performed before the effective date of the Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997. This includes adjustments to the accrual rate for employees and Members under specific paragraphs. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 amended provisions related to computing annuities for Members of Congress and Congressional employees. It includes adjustments to the accrual rate for employees and Members under specific paragraphs. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 amended contribution rates for Members of Congress and employees, including adjustments to deductions from pay and government contributions. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 amended contribution rates for Members of Congress and employees, including adjustments to deductions from pay and government contributions. Amendments were made to remove references to Members in certain subparagraphs. The Congressional Annuity Reform Act of 1997 amended contribution rates for Members of Congress and employees, including adjustments to deductions from pay and government contributions. The Act will take effect after the next election of Representatives, and the amendments regarding annuities will apply to those commencing on or after the effective date.
